item.title: Journalism (work in progress)
item.dc:creator: silveja
item.content:encoded:
Jake I just read through this and made a few minor grammatical changes. You listed journalism's 9 core values, but one thing I would add is to mention the 6-8 core values that you say ESPN has broken
“Everything we do as Reuters journalists has to be independent, free from bias and executed with the utmost integrity.” Reuters, one of the oldest and most respected news agencies in the world, has a pretty standard set of core values; ones that all news agencies must follow in order to be deemed credible and legitimate. Unfortunately not all journalistic institutions take these goals to heart. Recently, ESPN has been leading the way in chronicling the Bernie Fine scandal at Syracuse. But here lies the problem. Instead of reporting the news as it comes out, ESPN is making sure they “own” the story, controlling the way information is released, how it’s portrayed, and doing various things to control the story instead of reporting it. The Pew Research Center, an award winning “fact tank,” sponsors the Project for Excellence in Journalism (PEJ), an initiative aimed at “…help[ing] both the journalists who produce the news and the citizens who consume it develop a better understanding of what the press is delivering, how the media is changing, and what forces are shaping those changes.” The book written by members of the organization: “The Elements of Journalism: What Newspeople Should Know and the Public Should Expect” by Bill Kovach and Tom Rosenstiel, which outlined nine core principles of journalism, won awards from Penn State, Sigma Delta Chi, and Harvard. In it’s coverage of the Bernie Fine scandal, ESPN violated at least six, and at worst eight, of those core values of journalism.
The Core Values described in the book are: 1. JOURNALISM'S FIRST OBLIGATION IS TO THE TRUTH 2. ITS FIRST LOYALTY IS TO CITIZENS 3. ITS ESSENCE IS A DISCIPLINE OF VERIFICATION 4. ITS PRACTITIONERS MUST MAINTAIN AN INDEPENDENCE FROM THOSE THEY COVER 5. IT MUST SERVE AS AN INDEPENDENT MONITOR OF POWER 6. IT MUST PROVIDE A FORUM FOR PUBLIC CRITICISM AND COMPROMISE 7. IT MUST STRIVE TO MAKE THE SIGNIFICANT INTERESTING AND RELEVANT 8. IT MUST KEEP THE NEWS COMPREHENSIVE AND PROPORTIONAL 9. ITS PRACTITIONERS MUST BE ALLOWED TO EXERCISE THEIR PERSONAL CONSCIENCE
ESPN, and more directly Mark Schwartz, first learned of the accusations of sexual abuse by Bernie Fine in 2002. A then thirty year old Bobby Davis went to the police with the accusations that Fine molested him while Davis was a ball boy for the Syracuse basketball team, but was informed that the statute of limitations had expired on the charges, which supposedly happened from 1984, when Davis was twelve, until 2000, when Davis was 27. Davis, after the police route didn’t go anywhere, went to the Syracuse Post-Standard and ESPN, as well as Syracuse University with the accusations, and provided all three with the names of four or five people who Davis said would corroborate his story, including his step-brother Mike Lang. All those Davis said would corroborate his story denied any knowledge of any abuse. After thorough investigations by all three institutions came up empty, the Post-Standard and ESPN felt the stories did not meet their requirements for publication, and Syracuse University deemed the matter closed. But then the Penn State/Jerry Sandusky scandal happened, and that supposedly gave Davis’s step-brother Mike Lang, now 45, the courage to come forward. The second accuser gave Schwartz and ESPN the corroboration they needed to run the story. In the interest of full disclosure, I am a very big Syracuse fan. Three members of my immediate family are grads, and I closely follow Syracuse’s football, basketball, and lacrosse teams. However, I also am a big fan of ESPN. I watch ESPN’s Mike and Mike in the Morning every morning, have three separate ESPN websites bookmarked, and have PTI and Around the Horn on iTunes. This is being written because a grossly dishonorable thing has been done, and I believe it to be wrong. This is not meant to be a defense or exoneration of Bernie Fine, as I am not saying that Fine is guilty or not guilty. My opinion of the matter is irrelevant. I am simply saying that the way ESPN has handled the reporting of the matter is deplorable. In the past, journalists would take the information coming in off the AP wire (a machine that printed AP stories coming in off of telegraph wires) at the end of the day, and write their stories for the next day’s newspaper with an emphasis on accuracy and writing talent. Now, in the Internet Age of instant news, the emphasis is on being the first to report a story, to “own” the story. The Penn State/Jerry Sandusky scandal was an embarrassment for ESPN. The Poynter Review Project used its role as ombudsman of ESPN to criticize the network’s coverage of the scandal, saying “With the biggest staff of sports journalists in the world, ESPN should have been leading the charge to ask tough questions and shed light on this scandal. Instead, it was the tiny Patriot-News in Harrisburg, Pa. out in front of the journalism pack.” They went on to emphasize that it took 72 hours for ESPN’s coverage to find the “appropriate moral outrage.” Most important in the Poynter Review Project’s column was their belief that “Doria (ESPN’s Director of News) didn't articulate a specific strategy that would have ESPN steering the story, rather than simply reacting to it. We were hoping to see more of the former early on in the news cycle. […] We were particularly dismayed Tuesday morning, when ESPN and its vast resources seemed to be behind the curve, failing to turn up new information or advance the story and instead sounding tone deaf to the nature of this story.” Now keep in mind, this coverage of the Penn State scandal was after the result of a three year police investigation and a 23 page grand jury report were made public outlining multiple allegations of sexual abuse by Jerry Sandusky, along with testimony from those involved and with the conclusion of the grand jury being that there was an institutional cover-up of the sexual abuse of multiple children. In other words, facts were known, inconsistencies ironed out, and legitimacies confirmed. It seems as though after these criticisms of their reporting of the Penn State scandal, ESPN has swung too far to the other side. Their reporting of the Bernie Fine scandal has the appropriate moral outrage befitting the Penn State story, one where facts had been previously discovered and vetted, and testimony taken and recorded. The fact that they didn’t “steer the story” and were outdone by the Harrisburg News is not a bad thing. In fact, it’s a very good thing. ESPN is not Big Brother. The 2nd core value of journalism is that journalists have a responsibility to the people, not to their organization. If all the journalism was to come from one place, such as the Poynter Review seems to want from ESPN, then it would be impossible to find varied points of view or unbiased coverage, two staples of journalism itself. Sometimes it is best for small, local organizations to take leads on important issues, as they rarely have large corporate interests, have fewer people to appease, and allow for the large media outlets to (hopefully) focus on the fair and equitable reporting and analysis of the information to the masses. Also, criticizing ESPN for not “steering” the story and merely “reacting” to it is offensive to the very core of journalistic integrity. A journalist should not attempt to control a story, to put his or her own spin on it. “Reacting” to a story is good journalism. Core Value #1 states “This "journalistic truth" is a process that begins with the professional discipline of assembling and verifying facts. Then journalists try to convey a fair and reliable account of their meaning." Nowhere in there is anything about controlling a story. In fact, the second sentence of the first Core Value of Journalism sounds a whole lot like reacting to information.

item.title: It's as Complicated as Black vs. White
item.dc:creator: feinsan
item.content:encoded: The recent tragedy immediately became a racial issue. When Trayvon Martin was shot on February 26th, the entire country seemed to suddenly become involved. But as unfortunate as this incident was, murder in America is not uncommon; in fact, there are over 40 murders a day in the United States. And yet this death has gathered significantly more media attention than any of the others in recent memory. The murder of Trayvon Martin has received the attention it has, simply because Trayvon was black, and his shooter, George Zimmerman, was not. Zimmerman prefers to identify himself as Latino, but most news sources have reported him as Caucasian. The blatant truth is that Trayvon Martin’s murder is only news because it has been labeled a racial hate crime, which it very well might not be. Black leaders like “Reverend” Al Sharpton have flocked to Florida to bring media attention to the incident, while also filling their pockets along the way. And their entire argument is based off the assumption that Zimmerman’s side of the story is false (there is a witness who has confirmed his story and a witness who has painted a different picture). Would Sharpton have gone to Florida if the victim had been an Irish Boy? Would NAACP leaders have even known about the incident if the victim had been Jewish instead? Would this incident been on the news if the shooter had also been black? Another civil rights leader, Jesse Jackson, was quick to declare that “blacks are under attack,” but it is statements like this by people like him that prohibit the racial equality that these people claim to be fighting for. Over the past few years there have been several incidents in which Caucasians were brutally murdered by minorities. While I am not saying that the Trayvon Martin Case deserves less media attention than it is getting, I do believe that these incidents deserved more attention than they got. In early 2007, a couple in Knoxville, Tennessee was carjacked, tortured, raped, and murdered by four men and one woman. This case failed to make national headlines, and is still not very well known. It was later said about the case “This [case] doesn’t fit any political agenda. It’s not a useful crime. Reverse the races and just imagine how the national media would cover the story of a young black couple murdered by five white assailants." While I am not defending any of those at fault, hate crimes have become an unfortunate double standard. Just last week, several African Americans attacked and lit on fire a thirteen year old white boy while yelling out “this is what you deserve, white boy.” This particular story has not been featured on any national news programs, but is just as disturbing as the Trayvon Martin Story. The media outcry for Trayvon Martin is appropriate, but for the wrong reasons. President Obama shouldn’t acknowledge this horrible tragedy just because he shares the same skin tone as Trayvon, or because his hypothetical son “would look like Trayvon.” And while it is difficult to defend George Zimmerman, could he really make out Martin’s ethnicity on a dark and rainy night while the teen was wearing a hoodie? Moreover, Zimmerman did have good reason to be armed: police had been called to the neighborhood 46 times last year, due to several robberies, some of which were armed robberies. In addition, Martin is far from the perfect kid as he has been made out to be; pictures accompanying several articles were altered to make him look more innocent and less like a ‘thug.' While Martin's personality does not justify his murder, he was known to have several tattoos, and he has been suspended from school several times for assault on a bus driver and for possession of marijuana with suspicion of distribution. Martin uploaded pictures to his Twitter account, which uses a handle with a very offensive racial slur (@NO_LIMIT_N***A), in which he is showing off gold teeth and several tattoos, and later giving the camera the middle finger. A witness confirmed George Zimmerman’s story, claiming that he saw Martin on top of Zimmerman, not the other way around, and that it was Zimmerman who was yelling for help. Maybe we shouldn’t be so quick to judge things as they might stereotypically appear. What happened to Trayvon Martin is a tragedy, but I do not believe that it should be made a racial issue. Because of one victim’s ethnicity, our country should not divide itself along strict racial lines. By making the issue a racial one, and therefore separating Americans, we are restricting ourselves from actually achieving the equality we all want. As of March 28th, 2012, George Zimmerman has not been arrested. An original picture of Trayvon Martin, which was altered in several news publications (below) The above photo was intentionally photoshopedd, apparently to make Martin look less like a thug and more like an innocent.

item.title: The Worst Company in America: EA Games?
item.dc:creator: graname
item.content:encoded:
Recently, Electronic Arts won the Worst Company in American award for 2012, beating out Bank of America. Naturally, an uproar followed. Many felt it was absurd that a video game company had been voted as being worse than a bank, and that gamers were being whiny or had very skewed prioities. However, I feel that the words of William Usher, a writer for cinemablend.com, sum up the sentiments of all who voted for EA:
"If you don't know why, it's not just over the Mass Effect 3 ending, it's over Origin [an online service that sells digital downloads], it's over Project $10 [which made purchasers of used games pay an extra $10 to access online feature], it's over early server closings, it's about DLC charity abuse, it's over them gutting studios like Pandemic, Westwood, Origin Studios and Bright Light, it's over the lawsuits, it's over the nickel-and-diming with Day-1 DLC, and everything else in between. If you didn't know any of that then you're not informed enough to say why people shouldn't have voted for EA."
So no, gamers are not just bitter over the Mass Effect 3 ending. They are tired of being taken advantage of, and this whole thing boils down to consumers becoming fed up with being exploited. Say Apple releases a new product, knowing that they will release a program update for sale the same day the product is released. People would utterly freak out and it would be all over TV, newspapers and other media. However, there seems to be a huge tendency of downplaying issues in the gaming industry as nothing more than the complaints of Xbox junkies with no lives. EA Games being voted the Worst Company in America is an affirmation of consumer discontent, but so long as customers continue to feed into the madness by continuing to buy content released the same day or content that is overpriced, EA will keep taking advantage.

item.title: Club Convention: Resume Padding or Genuine Interest?
item.dc:creator: kahnda
item.content:encoded: [caption id="attachment_1869" align="aligncenter" width="710"] Members of the Inkwell team recruiting new members[/caption] victoria: edited what was written so far. maybe get a quote from someone concerning the club convention instead of just stating that it "appeared to be a big hit." definitely mention some past clubs that perhaps were not as active and created solely for the pleasure of being able to state "founder and president" on resume, though you will probably not be able to get anybody on the record for that. you could interview deb schoman about the new club standards (i.e how they actually have to be productive), the specifics of when and why that was put in place. other people to interview: students who are NOT in any clubs vs. those in MANY clubs for their POVs. other possible research: myth or fact, juniors join and create clubs because they are just realizing the college deadline is approaching, what freshmen vs. old-hand seniors think. also, remember: less "I asked" and more "when asked" and please give the people you interview some explanatory epithets (e.g, senior Sydney Menzin, Director of College Counseling Lauren Carballo). otherwise, the story seems on the right track, keep up the good work! The recent club convention appeared to be a big hit with many students in attendance, but it begs the question: are students joining clubs out of genuine interest? Or, do they join for perks such as food, club apparel, and a college resume boost? To discover more about students' real motivation for joining clubs, I talked to senior Sydney Menzin, current president of the Diversity Club. When asked about what role clubs play in the college process, Sydney said, “I think that participating in clubs is a great way to explore your options and demonstrate your interests to colleges. However, make sure your intention is centered around the enjoyment of the experience, rather than simply having another activity to add to a resume.” After getting Sydney's opinion on the topic, I asked Mrs. Carballo of the College Office for her perspective. According to the Associate Director of College Counseling, “joining clubs is also important in the college process, as a student's resume shows potential colleges his or her interests and involvement. Colleges can, therefore, predict whether or not a particular student will be an active member or even leader in their community.” Clubs sometimes though are used as just "resume stuffers" to try (PRESENT OTHER SIDE OF THE STORY HERE; CLUBS AS CYNICAL RESUME STUFFERS, KIDS CREATING THEM AS JUNIORS, USE ANONYMOUS SOURCES IF NEED BE BUT TRY TO GET SOMEONE ON THE RECORD) So how exactly do we find the balance between? Although it’s important to build up your resume and make yourself as a candidate look strong and like a leader, it’s High School. There is an opportunity to create a balance by finding a club that grabs your interests as well as your attention to work hard and succeed in it. Friends Academy has so many clubs to offer and if there isn’t one that interests you, than start your own club! The point of Clubs is to take a break from the classroom and find something that you are truly passionate about and through that show your leadership skills and abilities to succeed. [caption id="attachment_1867" align="aligncenter" width="710"] Upper School students flooded the downstairs of the gym as a myriad of clubs surrounded the perimeter beckoned people to sign up.[/caption] [caption id="attachment_1858" align="aligncenter" width="710"] TASQUE (Teachers And Students for Quaker Education) attracted students to their booth with treats and a movie about conduct during meeting that was shown the week before.[/caption] [portfolio_slideshow]

item.title: Fall Fashion Update
item.dc:creator: valciev
item.content:encoded: Victoria: This seems a little out of season now, if it still hasn't been published. Maybe we can do a winter update instead? Katrina: Do we have pictures for this? Fall is usually the season for comfy sweaters and oversized scarves, but this season, fall is being shaken up with comebacks and new statement colors. The major colors being shown throughout the stores this season are burgundy, pumpkin orange and various jewel tones. The tweed pattern, which we all know and love, is also making a major comeback. We can be sure to see more of this classic pattern in various skirts and jackets this fall. If you are looking for a comfortable and practical pair of shoes, try a pair of oxfords.  Not only are they easy to wear with any outfit, but also stylish, affordable and in dress code! Have you ever seen bracelet stacks in magazines that consist of various metals and wondered how you could pull off this trend? The answer to successfully pulling off this trend of mixing metals is to include various textured bracelets in your stack.  For example, you should add bracelets with leather or woven material for a fun pop. In this statement, context is key, so add textures that contain various colors that will blend well with metallic colors!  Friends Academy students can find these trends at dress code friendly stores like JCrew, Orvis, Rugby, Old Navy, and Vineyard Vines!

item.title: Why should you learn to program?
item.dc:creator: dsilvia
item.content:encoded:
tasks:

  • ease into article
  • change format?
  • Why is cs compelling
  • title
 

Without software the world would be radically different.

Software surrounds you. From your microwave to you brand-new iPhone 5 that you can’t stop looking at, you interact with software multiple times a day. Whether you realize it or not, you depend on it to go about your day-to-day life. Yet still, the majority of people remain dependent on a select few to equip them with these powerful programs.  

A Computer Science Major?

Computer Science may not be for you, but you should definitely try it with some depth. My teacher in an introductory course to Computer Science made a reference exemplifying how one could possibly find a passion. He used the example of learning an instrument when young. Your mom or dad may have persistently forced you to practice that insipid instrument, but nonetheless you got good at it. You finally were allowed to quit and you did, but you soon realize that you like playing the instrument when it is not required. That’s why you need to try Computer Science and programming with vigor. It largely boils down to the fact that people like what they are good at. Perhaps computational thinking becomes second nature to you and you can write extensive and impressive programs. Maybe you’ve discovered a passion but rather invented one. Computer Science is not limited. Contrastingly, Computer Science has very few limits. There are departments for a large realm of people. One can program games, create movie special effects, write a program to help doctors store medical reports, and produce artificial intelligence. An innovator might even produce a department that doesn’t even exist at this moment. The field of computers and technology is expanding at an exceptionally high rate, simply because there is an perpetual desire for tools that complete tasks for us or entertain us.  

Not a Computer Science major? I still recommend you learn how to program.

A recent report came out that Stanford’s most popular major is now Computer Science and 90 percent of all students take at least one Computer Science course.

item.title: Boys Championship Varsity Basketball Game
item.dc:creator: kahnda
item.content:encoded: edits by victoria: photos? also, is it stonybrook or stony brook? The Boys Championship Varsity Basketball Game against Stony Brook was full of excitement on Tuesday night, March 5. We had a lot of support from the Friends Academy community. The basketball game came close to a victory, but unfortunately, in the end, we did not win. However, the scores were close throughout the game. At the end of the first quarter, FA had 11 and Stony Brook had 15. By the second quarter, FA fell a couple more points behind with a score of 13 for FA and 28 for Stony Brook. Our team during the half time had a serious meeting in which they set their minds to coming back and winning. This was shown at the end of the 3rd quarter when FA had 21 and Stony Brook had 28. Even though FA worked hard and played until the very end, it was not enough to win the game. The final score was 34 for FA and 43 for Stony Brook. Either way, the Friends Academy Boys Varsity Basketball team put up a great fight and had a terrific season. Until next year boys and congratulations to having made it to the championships!

item.title: The Mystery of Spring P.E.
item.dc:creator: muranan
item.content:encoded:
Since the founding of Friends Academy in 1876, The “athletes” that don’t play a spring sport have been forced to play badminton. But in 2013, the monumental decision to change the spring season’s Physical Education requirement from Badminton to European Handball was made… Thus begins our quest to discover the reasoning behind this controversial decision. So we figured we would start at the source of the problem… and ask the librarians…
Unfortunately Andy had accumulated 4 DP’s within the library this semester, and was therefore not permitted to be in the library. Our only results: another DP, and some very angry librarians.
It was a slow start to our journey but we didn’t lose heart and decided to take our questions to someone who was sure to have some interesting insight on the new P.E. arrangement, First Year Student and sophomore, Phillip Chen. Jonny and I weren’t surprised to find that the 16-year-old boy from China reflected a particular bias towards Badminton.
“I hate handball and I was really looking forward to a season of competitive badminton.”
He later informed us that when not playing hockey, he would spent his time at the NYC Badminton Club in Manhattan preparing himself for a grueling spring P.E. season. Furthermore Phillips handball team’s 0-2 records also contributes to his dislike of the sport.

item.title: The Uncovering True Female life at Friends Academy
item.dc:creator: perrygo
item.content:encoded: To the naked eye, the girls at Friends Academy seem to get a long very well. As a junior boy, I realize that this is definitely not the case. After 7 years at Friends Academy I’ve been privilege to be given a little bit on the inside of the Friends Academy girls life and realize that this is definitely not the case so I decided to take it upon myself to uncover this story. When I started my research on this topic, I decided to get a third parties opinion on this topic so I started to ask teacher. After talking to several teachers, I was able to find out that most of these teachers have similar views on female students: They appear to be friendly and enjoying themselves with each other. “Most girls look friendly to each other, laughing, and enjoying themselves.” Said one teacher. These teachers are very wrong on what is truly happening in the girl world. To start my research, I started to talk to some upperclassmen. Knowing these students for quite sometime now, I was able to pick up when they were lying. I kept getting consistent lies like “Yeah girls talk to each other just like boys do. Were just as close as guys and we feel like we can talk to each other about anything.” But in reality none of this is true. Why were these girls feeling hesitant to share how they really feel about each other? It can be from several different reasons: 1) They are embarrassed. They do not want to admit to a guy the truth about girls. 2) They did what most girl who I interviewed explained to me the basic girl actions, lied. After finishing interviewing the upperclassmen, I decided to interview the underclassmen. While talking to these girls I got the honest real truth about girls: Every girl secretly hates each other.  “Every girl is really dramatic, very obnoxious, two faced, so fake, not trustable, no such thing as a girl best friend, prone to text fights, prr but really doesn’t and catty” This is the overarching quote that I came up with after interviewing many girls. Theetends to like each othese are true to an extent that I saw it happen right in front of me. While talking to 5 freshman girls, they started to answer my questions. Later they gave me specific examples of these incident. They had so much hatred towards this girl that they wanted me to call out this person in my article. These girls showed me the true side of the girl life at Friends Academy. After my adventure to try to figure out the truths of the girl world I was able to uncover the mysteries of the girl world. All quotes will remain anonymous as asked by everyone who was interviewed. Although realistically this problem will not be solved soon, I encourage girls to work on these problems and hopefully eventually stop these girl problems. I thank everyone who took the time to be interviewed.

item.title: Male Fashion at Friends Academy
item.dc:creator: bahrpe
item.content:encoded: The gentlemen of Friends Academy have been looking awfully fashionable this fall.  The ever dapper bow-tie made a comeback last year in the male population at Friends Academy.  This year, bow-ties can be spotted quite frequently again across campus. Whether male students are securing clip-ons or tying knots, bow-ties will continue to make an appearance on campus (at least until I graduate). [Ask Mr. Lape about his love of bow ties- direct quotes are great for articles] The reintroduction of the cowl/shawl sweater in the sophomore class...[expand on these sweaters and get a quote from a sophomore who wears these sweaters] Sperry boat shoes have lost their laces and the men of Friends Academy must pick a side: the classic laces that often come undone or the new crisscrossed laces that are unconventional yet practical.  Perhaps, boys should just skip the Sperry controversy altogether and instead wear Cole Haan loafers. There are still some fashion questions for which the answer is still uncertain. Will Timberlands make a come back? Could students see the return of elbow-pads? How are the freshmen coping with the task of fastening a tie every morning? Only time, dress code, climate and clothing prices will determine the dominant male fashion trends this year.

item.title: Boy's soccer Class C championship
item.dc:creator: perrygo
item.content:encoded: Congratulation to the FA boys soccer team for winning states this year! In addition to winning states, the FA boy’s soccer team was ranked 6th over all in the state which includes all of the classes. The team was able to over come many challenges constantly being the underdog but proving that that was not the case. The boy’s team won most of their games in blow out fashion showing why they were state champs. During the playoffs the team was carried by their veteran senior captain Jonny Nierenberg. Constantly coming up with the big goal when the team needed it including the solo goal in the championship game. “It was a great team effort throughout the entire playoffs. Everyone was gave all their effort and without that we wouldn’t have won.” Said Jonny. The team also benefited by crucial throw ins by fellow senior, Patrick Moodhe. Moodhe has the raw ability to throw the ball across the field to the goal allowing his teammates a chance to head the ball and score. In fact, most of the goals scored during the playoffs were scored this way including the lone goal in the championship game. Needless to say, Patrick Moodhe’s monstrous throw ins helped lead the team to victory. After talking to junior Jason Baskind he told me that, “Moodhe has the most dangerous throw in in the league. No other team has this weapon. It is one of the most amazing weapons that any sports team has every had.” The team wasn’t just a team but a family. “We were a family, everyone on the team was apart of the game. Even the bench players who weren’t playing were apart of the game. Without the help of everyone we wouldn’t have won.” Said junior Thomas Frey. They were united as a team, which eventually helped, lead the team to victory. The team is very happy with their season and is upset that it is over. They thank the support of the school and everyone who came out to their games during the entire season. Congratulations to the boy’s soccer team on an amazing season.

item.title: Friends Academy Squash Team
item.dc:creator: muranan
item.content:encoded: I have participated in US Squash sanctioned tournaments since I was 9 years old. One of my favorite aspects of a US Squash tournament is the referee system. After each match, both the winner and loser have to officiate the next match on their court. Although this system can be frustrating for the loser (who probably just wants to go home) it also serves to create lasting friendships between opponents. The US Squash referee system basically forces fellow juniors to sit down together after their match and work together for at least half an hour. As you can imagine, after 8 years of tournaments, I have gotten to know a lot of junior players, and nearly all of them participate for their school’s squash team. Hence, I decided to start a squash team at FA. The team consists of roughly 15 kids, both beginners and tournament seasoned players, and we practice 3 days a week at the Creek Club. Mr. Nelson and my long time coach, Khaled Sobhy (a former top professional player from Egypt, and an internationally renowned coach) are serving as the team’s trainers. Throughout the season we hope to organize a few matches against nearby schools with squash programs, and our primary goal is to qualify for US Squash’s National High school Championship (an annual event hosted a Yale for the 80 best high school teams in the country).

item.title: Are Tutors Fair?
item.dc:creator: korreja
item.content:encoded:
A lot of students receive tutoring for classes and standardized tests, especially at Friends Academy. Are the tutored students cheating?
If the "tutors" are actually doing the academic work for the student, it is cheating.  The students may never get caught, but they probably know that what they are doing is wrong. and hopefully karma will catch up with them. If students hire their specific teachers, who have "inside" information about specific grading and testing in class, the tutoring is also cheating.  I am sure that many teachers would disagree, but the fact is that teachers cannot help but tutor to their tastes.  When the tutor is the classroom teacher, that innate bias gives an unfair advantage to one student over every other student in that class.  This is an advantage that outside tutors simply cannot provide.  Additionally, when school teachers tutor their own students it negatively affects the moral of the entire class due to the appearance of an unfair advantage. Having to cope with that suspicious atmosphere in the classroom, unfairly punishes the untutored kids.  (However, going to get extra help from a teacher on an unpaid basis is fine as long as all of the students have equal access to that free help.  If a teacher offers that free help to only some students, it would again be cheating. But that would be a favoritism type of cheating. Nothing to do with tutoring per se.)
If the tutors are outside hires paid to help students study or learn more efficiently and successfully then tutoring cannot be considered cheating.   Why? Because although tutoring may give some students an advantage over other students, attempting to improve oneself simply cannot be a crime.  Life is full of honest advantages and disadvantages.  Tutoring is just one more of them.  Other similar advantages might be the fact that some kids have nicer homes with better work spaces in which to do their homework. And some kids have higher IQs than other students.   Some kids have parents who discuss homework issues with them.  Some kids have siblings that have taken the classes in previous years and offer advice.  All of these situations (and many others) are advantageous, while not being cheating.
It is unfair that affluent students can afford tutors while less affluent students who need help cannot afford them.  But that does not make the use of tutors cheating.  It does however make the accomplishments of those who cannot afford tutors that much  more impressive.  Just like an athlete who makes varsity with no outside coaching, getting great grades without a tutor is something to be proud of.

item.title: Small Ways to Make a Difference in Earth Month
item.dc:creator: farahsa
item.content:encoded: Not only is it the beginning of spring, but it's also the start of Earth month! Earth month is significant because it reminds us to celebrate Earth's natural beauty. In fact, Earth day, April 22, is the most celebrated environmental event in the world. Earth Day marks the anniversary of the first environmental movement in America. In the 1970s, Earth Day sprung out of a proposal made by John McConnell, a peace activist from The United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) conference in California. The Earth Day Network coordinated the celebration of Earth Day (and Earth Month) with the purpose of increasing awareness about environmental issues. Today, Earth day is recognized and celebrated in 192 countries. The primary purpose of Earth Day is to encourage the public to appreciate and protect the environment. In an effort to protect our planet, we need to keep it clean. I’m sure we are all familiar with the famous “R’s”: reduce, reuse, and recycle. In addition, we need to be careful with purchases of items that come in wasteful packaging. Reuse your canteens rather than constantly buying drinks in plastic bottles and throwing them in the trash. If anything, recycle them! Step out of your comfort zone. Form a group of you and your friends and visit a park to help clean up a little bit. Even the simplest actions make a huge difference. Close the faucet when you’re brushing your teeth. If a faucet leaks one drop per second, about 1,300 gallons are going to waste. If it’s hot water, that’s even worse because it also wastes fossil fuels, resulting in more greenhouse gasses. Maybe you want to reduce your energy bill. Change your lightbulbs to Compact Fluorescent Lamps, or CFLs. Not only do they provide better light but they last ten times longer than regular bulbs. They only consume 1/4 the amount of energy and 90% less heat. If you really want to get in touch with earth, plant a tree! Along with providing shade, keeping homes cooler, but trees also grant $62,000 worth of air pollution control and $31,250 worth of soil erosion. There are infinitely many ways to celebrate and give back to our Earth to make it a healthier place. But remember, you should live everyday like it’s Earth day.

item.title: The “Fall” of the Friends Academy Athletes
item.dc:creator: valciev
item.content:encoded: Multiple concussions, torn ACLs, coupled with dozens of torn muscles and ligaments are testaments to the tough fall season every sports team is facing. Due to our previously successful seasons, FA has moved up to a class with larger and more competitive schools. This move is proving strenuous on our athletes and is causing the number of injured players to dramatically increase. On the Girls Varsity Soccer team alone, three concussions, one pulled knee and a severe ankle sprain have lead to several JV players being pulled up and helping out. This in turn creates a problem for the JV that was already lacking numbers. The Girls Soccer program is among the other fall sports teams who are low on numbers and have injured players resulting from physical games. Going forward, the athletic department will have to make decisions on ways to keep our teams in competitive leagues while making sure our rate of injury stays low.

item.title: Skin Lightening
item.dc:creator: whiteal
item.content:encoded: American girls, who have fare skin, are known for their desire to have tan skin. In order to do so they tan, spray tan or apply tanning cream to obtain the desired “sun kissed” look. Being tanned is beautiful, American’s believe this, but the billboards and magazines in other countries, like India, tell another story. India’s idea of beauty is having pale almost white skin. But its not just India, in Africa, Latin America and even Asia, women are glorified for having lighter complexions.  Similar to Americans, they find a way to alter their skin tones. How do they do it? They apply a variety of bleaching creams. It seems like applying a cream to alter ones skin tone is no big deal, because of the similarity to how Americans tan their skin to acquire beauty. Skin bleaching, like tanning, has its health hazards, but apart from the physical risks, skin bleaching is a mental health hazard as well. Skin bleaching can trigger self -hatred and racism, two very serious issues that can severely affect the mental health of a person. Americans love tanning their skin but the media industry is not preoccupied with sun kissed bodies. In American media, there is a diversity of skin tones. For example, Americans believe Tyra Banks and Gisele Bundachen are beautiful but they are not the same skin tone. On the other hand, In India the only way to enter the media industry, which includes film, television and modeling, is to have pale skin. These industries are fueling racism by discriminating against darker skinned Indians and making dark Indians feel as if they aren’t beautiful. [Will's Note: I'm not sure if this "American girl's being fair-skinned'  business is politically correct, what with the 12% of the country that is Black or African American. Some of these claims seem as though they came from a source, but there are no citations (i.e. "skin bleaching can trigger self-hatred and racism"). Grammer is a bit dubious. Oh, and if my criticisms weren't overwrought enough already, the thesis and closing sentences posit to different points, making for a rather feeble argument.]

item.title: Costumes
item.dc:creator: steinel
item.content:encoded: Halloween is one of the most exciting times of years, where todlers through adults, have the power to show of their creative, spooky, and silly side.  Halloween is not only a holiday celebrated by people all over the world, yet a culture that has developed, being celebrated in many different ways. A recent survey taken  by the National Retail Federation estimated that about $2.6 billion dollars will be spent by Americans this year on Halloween costumes alone.  This survey reveals that $1.2 billion of that will be spent on childrens costume, while $1.4 billion will be spent on adults costumes, leaving $330 million to be put towards pet costumes.  Also reported in this survey, are the type of costumes that are predicted to be the most popular this year.  Americans are predicted to choose traditional costumes, including vampires, witches, superheroes, animals, and princesses. These costumes are overall the top 10 most popular Halloween costumes on the internet. The two most   Other costumes on the list also have been popular for a long time, but may have received a recent boost from recent attention in pop culture. For example, in 2012 zombies were the ninth most popular costume for children, and the fifth most popular for adults. This year, they are seventh among children and fourth among adults. The NRF estimates the number of people masquerading as the dead should increase by more than a quarter million this Halloween. Marvel, DC Comics and the companies that produce superhero costumes also will have another big year. An estimated 4.1% of all people dressing up for Halloween said they planned to wear an action hero or superhero costume, the fourth most popular answer. And that is only among those who did not specify which hero they were going to be. Batman characters were the second most popular choice. Other Halloween favorites include Superman and Spider-Man. Halloween has always been considered a holiday for children. This year, however, according to the survey, there actually will be more adults wearing costumes. While adults and children share several of the same top costumes, there are notable exceptions. For example, princesses, by far the most popular costume for children, are only tied for 17th for adults. Vampires, the third most popular costumes for adults, are 13th for children. To identify this year’s most popular Halloween costumes, 24/7 Wall St. reviewed the National Retail Federation’s 2013 Halloween Consumer Spending Survey. The results are based on the number of adults and children who knew what they were going to be, with a million adults still undecided at the time of the survey. These are this year’s most popular Halloween costumes.

This concept calls for the completion of base civil service jobs or training, like sweeping the streets in exchange for any kind of government provided welfare.

item.title: Life Without The NFL
item.dc:creator: kylerosenbluth
item.content:encoded: It’s a scary thought, isn’t it? It’s something that seems impossible and very hard to imagine. We have been raised in a world where the NFL is more than a super-power. It is a presence that is in every corner of the nation. Seemingly everybody knows what those three letters mean. N.F.L… National Football League. It is an unbeatable force, an immovable object. And we may be seeing the end of it. Back in March, Dallas Mavericks (NBA) owner Mark Cuban said that he thinks that the NFL is heading towards the end. He believes that the NFL is getting too big to control. He was alluding to the NFL’s constant attempts to rule the world. The NFL wants football to be the only sport that anyone cares about, and they don’t even try to hide it. The NFL Draft usually takes place in April, but this past one was from May 8 until May 10. The NFL said that the reason it moved the date was because of a scheduling conflict at Radio City Music Hall, where the draft is every year. That’s where I call their bluff. You’re the NFL. You are by far the biggest and most popular league in professional sports. There are no scheduling conflicts for you. There is absolutely no doubt that if you want a certain venue at a certain time, it’s yours. Not to mention the fact that it is at the same exact place at the same exact time every single year. It’s not like if I came out of the blue and told the people at Radio City that I needed the stage during the Christmas Spectacular. It’s the freaking National Football League scheduling a yearly event that everyone in the country knows is coming. As if that wasn’t enough proof that the NFL was trying to take over the American sports world, Sports Illustrated recently released an article talking about the NFL’s TV deals in relation to other sports. It talked about how the NFL used to cooperate with Major League Baseball during the World Series and not schedule any games so that the two leagues were not competing for viewers. This year the NFL scheduled multiple games that conflicted with crucial MLB playoff games, including two during the World Series. Not only were the two games during the World Series, they were also in prime time. Not only were they during the World Series and in prime time, but each game also contained at least one team that wasn’t from a baseball market. For example, the Green Bay Packers and the New Orleans Saints are both from cities that don’t have baseball teams, and they both played in prime time during the World Series. By putting those teams in their respective games, the NFL was trying to maximize its viewership. If the NFL put the San Francisco 49ers and the Kansas City Chiefs (the two teams playing in the World Series) as two of the prime time matchups, it is safe to say that the majority of people would still watch the football games rather than the baseball games, regardless of the fact that the baseball games were far more significant. By choosing to put two non-baseball markets in the games, they made sure that both of those cities would have their focus on the NFL. If the Yankees were in the World Series and the Jets were on Thursday Night Football, many of the people in New York would watch the Yankees game if they coincided. However, if you were a Saints fan and the World Series was on and the Saints were on Monday Night Football, nearly the entire Louisiana market would be watching football. The NFL has its sights set on more than just America, however. They want to rule the world. Every year, the NFL plays multiple games in Europe, which is the league trying to grow its vast fanbase overseas. The Jacksonville Jaguars are a team that plays at least one game at London’s Wembley Stadium. Coincidentally, the Jaguars have been the subject of discussion about relocation for several years now. By making them play in London, the NFL is entertaining the thought of whether or not an NFL team can thrive in a foreign market. The NFL wants a team in Europe; there is no doubt about that. They also don’t want to take a team out of America. The NFL has publically commentated on the idea of adding new franchises. They have made it perfectly clear that if there is to be a team in a new market, in the United States or internationally, it is going to be an expansion team, rather than the relocation destination of a current one. The NFL has 32 teams, meaning that if they add another one in (for argument’s sake) London, than they will have to add a 34th to keep balance. But is there ever going to be too much? Historically, those things that grow too big to control end in a major collapse. When you think of things of historical significance that fell at some point, whether it be the Chinese Dynasties, the Roman Empire, or the British Empire (just to name a few), they all followed this pattern. Make no mistake about it—we are currently what can be deemed the NFL Empire. The National Football League is by far the most profitable league in the entire world, out-earning Major League Baseball by over $1 billion. Four of the top five most profitable leagues are major North American sports (football, basketball, baseball, and hockey), and the NFL reigns supreme in North America.

item.title: YouTube: The New Television?
item.dc:creator: Cade_Huseby
item.content:encoded:
We all know YouTube as that website you go to to watch Beyoncé’s latest music video or a forty-five minute compilation of cat fails, but since it’s beginning in 2005, the video sharing website has exploded in to so much more. There are currently 1,311 YouTube channels that have over one million subscribers, with the most subscribed channel having 36 million. As an avid YouTube user and creator since 2009, I have seen so much change in this online community and expansion into the mainstream media. For example, Grace Helbig, has become one of the most successful YouTubers, not for having nearly 40 million subscribers, but because how she has started bringing YouTube-like content to mainstream television across the globe.
Current thirty year old, Grace Helbig, started making YouTube videos in 2008 and since then has only excelled in her entertainment career path. Just this year she created a comedy talk show starring herself titled, The Grace Helbig Show, which was quickly picked up by E! network and aired in April of 2015. She is the first YouTuber to have her own network television show and will probably open the doors to so many more to do the same. Her show is, “a hybrid comedy show that features the comedienne’s fresh take on what's trending in pop culture, as well as exclusive interviews with various celebrity guests” (eonline.com). I have found that adults who most commonly tune into E!’s late night shows are confused by the “YouTube vlogger” format of the show and find it somewhat childish and unintended for them. There is also the factor of her online comedic success coming from the enjoyment from younger audiences who don’t have the same sense of humor or relatable topics in social culture. E! was clearly aware of the younger (13-18) audience they would gain from Helbig’s 2,500,000 subscriber base and tried to use that as a way to pull in more viewers, but with the show having a 10:30 EST time slot, most kids don’t tune in. Personally I have no urge to watch the show because of the already high level of accessibility of her content from her YouTube channel. In my opinion, although show has not gathered a large flock of viewers, the network made a, risky, smart decision by being the first to sign a YouTuber to a show because of how much more popular, accessible, and enjoyable the online culture has become.
In conclusion, YouTube has opened up incredible opportunities throughout the entertainment world. I think that this joining of platforms will definitely take a while to settle as a, “community norm” to the current adults of our culture, but in the long run will become a really fun collaborative effort. A lot of my friends, and myself, factually watch YouTube more than T.V. all the time and I think that more people will start to catch this habit as our entertainment industry progresses.

item.dc:creator: howarka
item.content:encoded:
Visiting colleges can be an extremely awkward experience. College is a very important time in your life, and picking a college is a big decision. A key part in making this decision is visiting schools in order to determine what kind of school is right for you. Luckily, there are a wide variety of schools that offer an even wider variety of experiences. There is a school out there for everyone, no matter your passions and interests. The only struggle is finding the school that is best for you. Going on college tours is certainly an experience, which can either be good or bad. You will go to a school and within the first few minutes know whether you like it or not. You will walk into some schools and love them instantly, and walk into others and know that you would never go there. Fortunately, seeing the colleges that you dislike will give you clarity about the ones you do like. Tours on every campus, however, whether you decide that you like the school or not, can be awkward. Tour guides are given a big responsibility in showing off their school to a large group of people, and this doesn’t always go over well. Sometimes the tour guide isn’t loud enough or the people on the tour aren’t receptive enough; a lot can go wrong. And, often, these tours are what really draw you to or away from a school. The experience you have on a tour has a large effect on you, so in general it is important that these go well. There are certain things tour guides will definitely, and should, tell you. You should be made aware of the rigor of the academics, the requirements, and the overall course of your academic career. They should go over basic information like the types of courses offered, the average class size, the student-to-faculty ratio, and when you declare your major. They generally also inform you of what student life is like both on and off campus. The percentage of students that live on campus and what the area is like around the school tend to greatly shape the way social life at that school works, so it is important to take note of the area around it and see if you could see yourself enjoying life there. Your tour guide should also inform you of any major opportunities that the school offers, such as study abroad programs, research opportunities, internships, sports, theater, and clubs. You’ll hear about tour guides taking people to the wrong location, running into college students doing things they shouldn’t have been doing, and talking about inappropriate subjects, and it is important to realize that every single thing your tour guide says and does is a reflection of the school: good or bad, these things are worth hearing and noting. That being said, a few key things come into play on a college tour. First of all, you yourself have to be open to the experience, as do the people you are with. If you walk into a school with a closed mind, you won’t get very far. It is also important to take advantage of this opportunity. Learn more about the school, life on and off campus, and ask questions—the tour guide doesn’t have enough time to cover everything, but they do know what it’s like first hand to be a student at the school. Pay attention to the kind of people you see, whether they seem happy or not, and try to decide whether you could see yourself at the school.   10 Things Tour Guides Shouldn’t Say:  
  1. “I hate my roommate.” - No one wants to hear this, especially when they’re already stressed out enough about finding people to be friends with.
 
  1. “All we do here is work.” - Work is great, but I’m pretty sure there’s much more to experience in college than just work.
 
  1. “If you don’t join a sorority you probably won’t have many friends.” - Sororities are great, but not for everyone.
 
  1. “My boyfriend slept in my room last night, so I’m hoping he won’t still be there when we tour my dorm.” - This is just too much information. Way too much information.
  1. “I’m actually leaving after this year because I don’t like it here.” - This is never, ever, a good thing to say while giving a tour. It automatically makes the people on it feel both uncomfortable and worried that they’d end up feeling the same way.
  1. “I had a different school as my top choice, but I didn’t get in so I came here.” - This makes it seem as if the school isn’t that great since it was the tour guide’s second choice. Of course, this could be the reality for many tour guides; however, that isn’t something they should be sharing. They should be trying to sell the school, and emphasizing all of the good things about it.
  1. “The food is pretty bad.” - This isn’t a deal breaker; however, it is important that the food on campus is good.
  1. “The dorm rooms are really small and the bathrooms are disgusting.” Considering that the people on the tour are thinking of spending the next four years of their lives in one of those dorms, this is not the best thing to say. (However, it does give everyone a warning for what they could end up being stuck with.)
  1. “Not everyone here is very nice, but I have a couple of good friends.” - It’s obvious that anywhere you go there will be people that aren’t nice. There is no need to say this on a tour.
  1. “I’m really excited to go home soon!” - Seeing family and friends is great, however, when a tour guide says this it makes it seem as if they are eager to get out of there… which is not exactly a good thing.
  10 Things People On Tours Shouldn’t Do:
  1. Let parents control the tour. - Students should walk in front of their parents and ask questions if they feel the need to; the parents should take a step back since, well, they’re not the ones actually going to college.
  1. Ask too many questions. - It is good to ask some questions and show interest, however, asking too many questions just gets annoying and overwhelming.
  1. Talk too much. - If you are on a tour it is important to respect the tour guide and the school.
  1. Wander around. - Don’t stray from the tour! It is important to follow the tour guide and stay on track. If you have questions or want to see another area of the school just ask- tour guides are usually more than willing to show you around other spots on campus. If you’re planning on leaving the tour early, you should probably notify the tour guide at the beginning of the tour. Leaving randomly is both awkward and impolite… and you don’t want to get lost.
  1. Talk on the phone, or use a phone in general. - It’s rude. Speaking on the phone disrupts the tour guide and all of the other people on the tour. Looking at your phone is rude as well: you should be paying attention to the tour guide and your surroundings. You don’t want to miss anything!
  1. Complain. - If you’re tired, want to see something specific, or can’t hear, don’t complain. Tour guides are always willing to help you, so if you want to speak to them about something ask them politely.
  1. Arrive late. - Arriving late to a tour is both unprofessional and awkward. It is important that you actually arrive around 10 minutes before your tour starts, as there is a sign in process and often somewhere else you have to go to meet your tour guide.
  1. Wear heels or other uncomfortable shoes. - Though you are supposed to dress somewhat nicely for a tour, make sure you’re wearing comfortable shoes. Tours often require a lot of walking all around a campus. Tours generally take around an hour, unless you go to an information session which adds on another hour. The hour spent on the tour consists of a lot of walking that can be up and down hills and actually quite tiring.
  1. Take too many photos or videos. - As previously stated, it is rude to use your phone during a tour. Taking pictures is okay, but only in moderation. Do not take pictures or videotape your tour guide, especially without their permission. If you see a spot on campus that you really want to remember, it is okay to snap a picture of that, but otherwise photo taking should be kept to a minimum. You do not want to seem like paparazzi.
  1. Be afraid. - Do not be afraid to ask the tour guide questions. Though some topics should definitely be avoided while on a tour, your tour guide is there as a resource for you and can answer and questions and address any concerns you may have. Take advantage of this opportunity to learn more about a school through a student, as no one can better describe the experience than a student currently living it.

item.title: Children's Medical Fund Raise Fest featuring The Chainsmokers
item.dc:creator: noelle_munao
item.content:encoded:
-how was it, where was it
-who were the opening acts
-what was the cause/why

     Children’s Medical Fund is a 501 ©(3) nonprofit dedicated to provide ongoing funding for programs that are vital to the needs of seriously ill children and their families at Steven & Alexandra Cohen Children’s Medical Center. 

"Our mission is to help every child patient and their families cope with the challenges of a hospital experience, so that every day a child spends in care is a better day. Our programs are designed to meet the needs of seriously ill children and their families. Your donations, time and support fuel the lifeblood to achieving those goals. Over the years, CMF has raised funds to purchase much needed medical equipment and support research in areas such as pediatric oncology and neurology." 

- See more at: http://www.cmfny.org/our-noble-programs/#sthash.xJlJSlLd.dpuf

item.title: The Kindle Fire
item.dc:creator: ReedR95
item.content:encoded: On September 28th, Amazon shocked the tech world with the announcement of their newest Kindle. Their new “Kindle Fire” is a tablet with a 7 inch multitouch display, with a higher resolution than the iPad. It has a dual core CPU, wifi capability, and runs a very custom version of Google’s Android tablet operating system, Honeycomb. With access to Amazon’s huge library of content, including books, magazines, TV shows, music, and movies, this device will be killer for content consumption. It is also able to download applications and games from Amazon’s new app store and browse the web with Amazon’s Silk browser. Did I mention that it only cost $199? Although the Kindle Fire does not match the iPad’s features, at $199 it will be a huge seller for Amazon. Not only has Amazon managed to come up with a tablet that is cheaper than the iPad, but they are the first company competing with Apple that has actually came up with something new, not just another wanna-be iPad. We got our first glimpse of the iPad when it was first announced in January of 2010, at the Yerba Buena Center in San Francisco. Steve Jobs showed off its most prominent features and capabilities at the keynote announcement. We saw the iPad compose emails, create documents in the iWork suite, and later, when garageband was announced, we saw the iPad making music. In addition to being a great tool for content consumption, the iPad was touted as a creator, something that you could easily use instead of a laptop or personal computer. The Kindle Fire is completely different. Our first view of the new Kindle in action was during its announcement event. Jeff Bezos, Amazon’s CEO, gave the audience a demo of the new product. He showed us that the new Kindle can read books, watch videos, play music, and even play games downloaded from their app store. It was briefly mentioned that the Kindle Fire would have an email client, but it was not even demonstrated. It is quite obvious that the direction Amazon is going with their Kindle Fire is quite different from the one that Apple took. Unlike the iPad, the Kindle Fire was designed purely for consuming content. This is made even more obvious by the fact that it costs Amazon $10 more to manufacture the Kindle Fire than the price they are selling it for. So if they aren’t making money off of it, than why do they bother? The Kindle Fire (like previous Kindles) is simply a gateway for Amazon to reach more potential customers. Now, instead of just selling books with through their Kindles, they can now sell video, music, and apps, and the fact that all of this content is so easily accessible only makes the tablet more appealing. So… Do I think the Kindle Fire will be a huge success? Absolutely. Do I think it will be an iPad killer? Not at all. The Kindle Fire will certainly cut into the iPad’s sales a little, but I think each device has its own, completely different market. I think that Shawn Blanc hit the nail on the head when he wrote “The Kindle Fire is a portable media center, not a portable computer”.

item.title: The Spherical Future of Video Games
item.dc:creator: graname
item.content:encoded:
While its appearance is that of a gargantuan stationary hamster ball, the Virtusphere’s capabilities far exceed those of any pet toy, and any human toy for that matter. Gamers are equipped with virtual reality goggles and placed inside the Virtusphere. Once inside, they are free to “walk” in any direction and able to “see” where they are going. The ability of the ball to rotate in any direction allows gamers to walk and look anywhere they want, allowing complete and total freedom in the virtual environment. Its capabilities, while perfect for video games, are also marketed towards other sectors such as museums, architects, and the military. Museums can use them as virtual exhibits, architects can be given a three-dimensional look at their blueprints, and the military uses it to train soldiers more realistically.<!--more-->
Despite its potential for creating the most awesome gaming experience ever, there are some drawbacks. For example, many people reported that getting used to moving around in the Virtusphere was difficult, making inexperienced users feel awkward and off balance. In terms of price, the Virtusphere is not cheap by any stretch of the imagination. In fact, cost remains its biggest obstacle to widespread use. Few people are willing to lay out upwards of $50,000 for a video game accessory. So while the Virtusphere is not likely to be installed in someone’s living room or the FA social space, the government and other large organizations have found the contraption to be quite useful.

item.title: The FASchedule iPhone App
item.dc:creator: ReedR95
item.content:encoded: Last year I began working on an iPhone app. It was pretty basic at first, in fact, it only had two buttons. The app contained two images, one of my A week schedule and one of my B week schedule, and the buttons I mentioned before simply switched between the two images. Since then the app has evolved. Now, the Friends Academy “Block” schedule is hardcoded into the app. This means that FA students who download the app can specify which class they have for each block as well as their lunch period, and the app will instantly generate a digital version of their schedule. The app even senses what time it is, and throughout the day shows you your current class, tells you what your next class is, and displays a progress bar that shows how far into each class you are. To give you a better idea of how this all works, here are some screenshots. [gallery link="file" order="DESC"] A lot of thought and hard work has gone into making this app functional and fast, and I am happy to say that it is now available in the App Store: http://itunes.apple.com/us/app/faschedule/id472827413?mt=8 If you like using this app, please check out Applause Code, an app development company that I started with my dad and brother. We are hoping to release a bunch of apps throughout the year, and currently have a game called "Drop!" for sale in the App Store.

item.title: “Champions for Charity”
item.dc:creator: menzisy
item.content:encoded: During the weekend of December 1st-3rd, the Americana Manhasset and Wheatley Plaza shopping centers are hosting the 16th annual “Champions for Charity” event. There are 90 non-profit organizations that benefit from this fundraiser, including Friends Academy’s own Diversity Grant Fund. Members of the FA community, along with the general public, can participate by registering for a special Champion Card to use at the event. The Diversity Club respectfully requests that people select its Grant Fund as their charity of choice. Twenty-five percent of the money spent will go to this worthy cause, and any sized contribution is greatly appreciated. The Diversity Grant Fund has been extremely successful in distributing financial aid to members of the school who apply for monetary assistance for expenses that include “art supplies, AP tests, calculators, musical instruments and Driver's Education,” said Sophie Fritz ’12, the President of the Diversity Committee. Requests are anonymous and never denied. The fund supports the Diversity Club’s idea of equal opportunity for all. By creating this financial resource, the Club is making progress in preventing the exclusion of those who cannot afford certain necessities of an FA student.   The “Champions for Charity” weekend is an event that many meaningful organizations greatly profit from. Please consider participating and share information about it with friends and family! To register, please click this link: https://nt6.magma.ca/championsforcharity/register/add.asp For further inquiries regarding applications to receive aid from the Diversity Grant Fund, please contact Mrs. Clark.

item.title: Quick and Easy Online Shopping
item.dc:creator: rechlga
item.content:encoded: This week’s fashion website: shopbop.com Many FA students, including myself, go on shopbop.com in the hopes of finding a new dress, jacket, and maybe even a pair of boots… But do any of us really know how to use it? Category labels line the top of the website and indicate where you can find the specific items you’re looking for. But, what if you are just browsing and aren’t sure what you want? What is the fastest, simplest way to find a fun new look? While bored on my computer one day, I went onto shopbop, and clicked the clothing label. I had no look in mind; rather I needed an outlet to forget about the stressful day ahead. I felt overwhelmed by the amount of choices that lay in front of me. After a good twenty minutes of scrolling up and down the website, I came across the label called Lookbooks. This tab opened up a whole new world for me of online shopping; a world that takes up hardly any time and is virtually stress-free. Lookbooks contain pictures of the latest fashion trends, on and off the runway. It even shows you different ways to wear certain pieces; this gives you the ability to find a cute, trendy and fantastic outfit in less than five minutes! Multiple consumers and designers make Lookbooks; therefore, there are a variety of styles and ideas giving an option to almost anyone! So, when you’re stressing about schoolwork and need to take a break, go to shopbop.com and click on Lookbooks. I guarantee you find a look you’ll love; and in under five minutes!

item.title: Trends of Fall and Spring
item.dc:creator: valciev
item.content:encoded:
Fall 2011 is here, and it is time for girls to get shopping. Fashion week in Paris and New York is always a good indicator of what people will be wearing around town (and campus) these days. This season, fashion week set some major trends in outerwear, and fabrics for fall, as well as patterns and themes for spring. In addition we learned that colors don’t have to be neutral, and some long standing fashion rules can finally be broken.<!--more-->
For fall:
For outerwear, Capes and Ponchos are definitely in. Anything goes, from tailored to bohemian. If you want to stick to the more traditional jacket, a military jacket or a varsity style are the looks of the moment.
Finally, FA girls will be stylish while staying in code, as long hemlines are in for fall. Miniskirts are being replaced with knee length skirts and the styles are classic or bohemian.
As for colors, no need to stick with traditional fall neutrals. Designers are showing that fall clothing can be colorful, and Polka dots and dainty prints are no longer reserved for spring. In the past nobody would have dreamed of white after Labor Day, and now the top designers are sending white down their runways.
Most likely inspired by the royal wedding, hats are making a comeback this fall. This trend is very versatile, as anything goes, from a military to a floppy to a fedora. If you are too self consciousness to make this kind of statement, you can get a furry hat, or cap that covers you ears, making you look both fashionable and practical.
For spring: (if you are interested in getting a little head start on your shopping)
Marc Jacob’s spring collection accented loafers this year. FA girls stick to flats for the most part, so if you want to be original, and take a fashion risk, loafers are a good start.
Just like the fall, bold colors are staying in for spring. This trend was especially used in the lines of Milly and Nanette Lepore. As for patterns, nautical is a big one. This pattern is a horizontal blue and white stripe, which looks great on a sweater or bag.
Last but not least, a bowler bag for this spring is a must. Not only has it been used in almost all of the runway shows, but this style bag is being carried by almost all of the celebs. These bags are roomy and light, perfect for a day in the city or even just a walk around town.

item.title: FA Cross Country
item.dc:creator: blumjo
item.content:encoded: The FA Cross Country team has enjoyed a lot of success this season.  Both teams, boys and girls, are in first place in their respective divisions and the majority of members from each team set new personal bests.  In addition to these personal accolades, the teams has really seemed to bond as a group. The season was highlighted by a trip to Brown for the top seven boys and girls on each team. Both teams won the Class C Championship! This victory was followed by a 5+ hour bus ride at 7am on Friday up to the state meet in Utaca, NY. On Saturday the two teams went to Vernon-Verona Sherill High school with about 100 other runners from Nassau County for the race. In their races, the FA runners put up a good fight as they battled about 150 other runners in the State, and had to endure a grueling 3 miles of battling cold, hills, and LOTS AND LOTS of mud! The boys team finished 8th in the state and the girls team finished 7th. Our very own Kelsey Margey, 12,  took the bronze medal home! Top seven girls: Kelsey Margey, Katrina Garry,  Molly Sullivan, Sunny Lostritto, Katie Pappas, Rosie Mangiarotti, Emily LeoGrande Top seven Boys: Glenn Lostritto, Patrick Crowley, Sahil Massand, Evan Sayre, Rob Adams, John O'Brien, Will Duke [caption id="attachment_190" align="alignnone" width="434" caption="Freshman Glenn Lostritto leads the Pack at the Brown Invitational"][/caption]   [caption id="attachment_296" align="alignnone" width="432" caption="Patrick Crowley coming into the finish line on Saturday"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_188" align="alignnone" width="313" caption="Senior Kelsey Margey wins Northeast Championship"][/caption] [caption id="attachment_298" align="alignnone" width="384" caption="Molly Sullivan and Katrina Garry at States"][/caption]   [caption id="attachment_189" align="alignnone" width="372" caption="Junior Evan Sayre at Brown Invitational"][/caption]   For Stats of the Friends Academy Cross Country Team visit: http://NY.milesplit.com/teams/FRNDS

item.title: Your Nose Knows it's Spring!
item.dc:creator: pettwsh
item.content:encoded:
Shekinah Pettway ‘14 Spring time is here and so are your allergies! This spring 2012 allergy season is said by researches to be the worst ever, but why is this so? A study published in the proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences found that the length of ragweed season in various areas of the U.S. increased by as much as 27 days between 1995 and 2009. Are the different lengths of ragweed the culprit? Instead, researchers say climate change is the reason for such a powerful coming allergy season. Because of the unusually warm weather this winter, the allergy season has come early this year and “hit with a wheezing vengeance!”
According to Doctor Stanley Fineman, president-elect of the American College of Allergy, Asthma and Immunology and an allergist at the Atlanta Allergy and Asthma Clinic, "The seasons are getting longer—they're starting earlier and pollens are getting released earlier." Not only is weather the problem, but CO2, or carbon dioxide percentage is high in the air. It feeds plants and leads to a greater release of pollen, and sometimes that pollen is more potent and more allergenic than it was when there was less CO2 in the atmosphere. So, the real question is…how can we avoid experiencing all the sneezing, runny noses, congestion, itching, etc.?
Here are some suggested solutions: 1. Know what triggers your allergies. You may not be experiencing symptoms from pollen and the air around you, but some factors could be mold or fungus, which are exacerbated by April showers 2. Keep your windows shut and try to stay inside on dry days. Once you have located you’re the trigger to your symptoms it is best that you avoid them in any way possible 3. Rid all kitchen chemicals. Household cleaning items can aggravate or even cause both indoor and outdoor allergies. a. Triclosan, the active ingredient in antibacterial soaps, has been tested to be the cause of many indoor allergy sufferers. 4. Watch what you eat. Your body’s immune system can identify a similarity between the proteins of pollen and the proteins of fruit. When your allergies are at its worst it is best to eat leafy greens. “Climate chaos is hammering for your health!” So try your best to do right for your body so that this allergy season can be a little less sneezy!
Work cited: http://www.kansas.com/2012/03/25/2270474/mild-winter-is-bad-news-for-spring.html#storylink=cpy
http://abcnews.go.com/Health/AllergiesSeasonal/spring-2012-worst-allergies/story?id=15930328&page=2#.T3COBzGvKSo

item.title: Avengers to the Rescue!
item.dc:creator: pettwsh
item.content:encoded: edited by victoria wang, needs another edit Shekinah Pettway                                                                                          May 12, 2012 Movie Review: The Avengers Marvel returns with its vanquishing box office arrival, the Avengers! A star squad of Marvel superheroes, including Iron Man, the Hulk, Thor, Hawkeye, Captain America and Black Widow, come together when an unexpected enemy emerges that threatens global safety and security. This action-packed movie has been a hit, making $200.3 million in theaters in one week. The New York Times gives the record-breaking blockbuster a whooping 5 stars. The Avengers is brilliantly directed, filled with humorous, daring, and thrilling scenes. It is also stuffed to the brim with special effects, including 3D availability. The characters popping out at you throughout intense action will make the movie even more enjoyable. Vivid color variations and a variety of dynamic settings throughout the movie add to the appeal. For all Marvel fans, the Avengers will be like a dream come true! All of the most powerful superheroes cooperating together to save the Earth from doom - what could be any better? So run, don’t walk, to the nearest movie theater. Grab your 3D glasses, sit back, relax and enjoy the Avengers, and don’t forget the popcorn!
